message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the cranial nerve involved is the vagus nerve, specifically the auricular branch. A peripheral lesion of the vagus nerve would manifest with ipsilateral vocal cord palsy, as this branch of the nerve also innervates the larynx. None of the other options are related to the function of the vagus nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms indicate that the cranial nerve involved is the vagus nerve. Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy is a potential manifestation of a peripheral lesion of the vagus nerve. The other options are associated with other cranial nerves.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the cranial nerve involved is the vagus nerve. Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy is a common manifestation of vagus nerve lesions. None of the other options involve the vagus nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the nerve being affected is the glossopharyngeal nerve. Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy is a manifestation of a peripheral lesion of this nerve. All other options are not related to the glossopharyngeal nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coughing symptom when cleaning the ear suggests the involvement of cranial nerve IX, also known as the glossopharyngeal nerve. Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy is most likely to be caused by a peripheral lesion of this nerve. The other options are not directly related to the glossopharyngeal nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the cranial nerve involved is the vagus nerve, and a peripheral lesion can cause ipsilateral vocal cord palsy. The other options are not related to the vagus nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely affected nerve is the vagus nerve, which innervates the larynx and can cause coughing when irritated. Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy would be a common manifestation of a peripheral lesion of this nerve. The other options are not related to the symptoms or affected nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the nerve affected is the vagus nerve, which is responsible for cough reflex. Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy is a manifestation of dysfunction of the vagus nerve. Inability to raise the ipsilateral eyebrow is a manifestation of dysfunction of the facial nerve. Decreased secretion from ipsilateral sublingual gland is a manifestation of dysfunction of the submandibular ganglion. Ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss is a manifestation of dysfunction of the cochlear nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that stimulation of the left ear is triggering the cough reflex, which is most likely due to the irritation of the vagus nerve. Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy is the most likely finding on physical examination because of the involvement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which is a branch of the vagus nerve that controls the function of the vocal cords. The other options are not related to the function of the vagus nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest irritation of the vagus nerve, which plays a role in coughing. Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy is a manifestation of a peripheral lesion of the vagus nerve. The other options are not related to the vagus nerve.
